newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Analysts mixed on KLM share buy-back.
newsitem.headline: Analysts mixed on KLM share buy-back.

text.p: Dutch carrier KLM's buy-back of around one billion guilders' worth of state-owned shares gained a mixed reception from analysts on Thursday.
"In the short term it's a very nice move, but in the long term it will not make any contribution to corporate growth," said Gert Jochems, airlines analyst with broker NIB Strating.

KLM said on Thursday it was buying back and withdrawing 17.3 million state-owned ordinary shares at a cost of around one billion guilders, thereby reducing the Dutch government's stake to 25 percent from a current 38.2 percent.
Other analysts said the fact that KLM was involved in what was essentially an asset management move could be construed as a sign that it lacked strategic imagination.
"In the absence of business style you get asset management," said an analyst who declined to be named.

Corne Zandbergen of Generale Bank said buy-backs could be interpreted as a sign of weakness, but added: "One should not see it so negatively. In the U.S. it is quite customary for companies to buy back their own shares."
"It's sensible for KLM to do something with their cash pile and this is an effective way of using it given it will boost earnings per share," Zandbergen said.
"Nevertheless it's a one-off move...real improvements to the quality of earnings will still have to come from their Focus 2000 (restructuring) programme," he said.
A reduction in the state stake could also make KLM more attractive to foreign investors and possible partners, although government interference in the airline had never been a problem.
"I can see that the division (between state and airline) could be more sharply drawn...Majority state-owned airlines have a bit of a bad name," Zandbergen said.

"The reduction of the state's stake is an ideologically important step," analyst Bert Hoogenhuyze of brokers Amstgeld agreed. "The U.S. will see the way KLM is headed...that it's definitely not a state dependent like, say, Air France."
As such its chances of a link-up with other commercial airlines could be enhanced, and merger speculation would continue to underpin the stock's price, he said.
Jochems said he was unhappy at the increase in gearing resulting from the reduction in shareholders' equity.
"Gearing will go back up to 130 percent (from 95 percent) -- I think that's on the high side," he said, adding KLM had always targeted a net debt to equity ratio of less than 100 percent.
But Zandbergen said he did not regard this as a problem, seeing it as a temporary, unavoidable setback in a continuing drive to improve equity ratios.
"You can't have your cake and eat it," he said. "Focus 2000 will put the company back on course."
Generale had reduced its KLM recommendation to hold after the shares picked up to 47 guilders on news of the buy-back.
"We had it on a structural hold prior to last week's news the company was planning a buy-back, after which we upgraded to a trading buy," Zandbergen said.
"At this price (47-48 guilders) the shares are once more a hold," he said.
-- Lien van der Leij Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000
